> Are we going to need a method in FiniteAppenderatorDriver to return a list of the active sequenceNames? Currently, the KafkaIndexTask "knows" what it is because it's provided by the supervisor as baseSequenceName and it just adds a partition number. But if it's cycling through lots of them then it might need some more help.

@gianm would you elaborate on how you are thinking to use active sequenceNames for KafkaIndexTask? I'm not sure how it is helpful.

Here is the official download link.
http://druid.io/downloads.html
Needs one more design review.

In fact, I tried to alter the code. It seems that there are two places that needed to be changed:
BITS_FOR_BUCKETS 
bucketMask;
Both of them are in HyperLogLogCollector.java.

Do you mean the original value from your input data? It's not preserved (HLL is lossy) so you can't decode that. But you can load it into a Druid HyperLogLogCollector object if you want to look at it -- check out HyperUniqueSerde for an example.
@gianm thx,that really helps

> @gianm would you elaborate on how you are thinking to use active sequenceNames for KafkaIndexTask? I'm not sure how it is helpful.

I was thinking that KafkaIndexTask has to call `driver.add(row, sequenceName, committerSupplier)`. Currently the sequenceName is part of the ioConfig of the kafka task. But if the task is doing incremental handoff, and each increment has a different sequenceName, what would the task do when it is saved to disk and then restored? How would it know what sequenceNames to use?

ProtoTestEventWrapper.java is a generated class using the protobuf compiler.   It seems the file was further modified by some kind of tool (Error Prone?) in the master branch besides the license header.  IMO we shouldn't edit the generated code unless absolutely necessary.  To fix the conflict, I have to apply the same tool, but I don't know how.

@knoguchi I think it'd be fine to re-generate the file using the generator, and add exclusions for it to the errorprone config. For example see common/pom.xml where antlr-generated files are excluded from certain checks. The config looks like this:

```
                    <plugin>
                        <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                        <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                        <configuration>
                            <compilerArgs>
                                <!-- Antlr-generated classes miss @Override, that is not easy to fix -->
                                <arg>-Xep:MissingOverride:WARN</arg>
                            </compilerArgs>
                        </configuration>
                    </plugin>
```

I mean the property form in the select-query.md has a problem that it lack of the "granularity".

there is no inbuilt filter type `columnComparison` , if you wrote a custom filter in an extension then either that extension is not loaded or filter is not correctly mapped to name `columnComparison`

i see, it is introduced recently and not released yet, see http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0/querying/filters.html for the docs of 0.10.0 release. it will be available in next release of druid.

@drcrallen replaced usages of `String.getBytes()` and `new String()` with fast methods from `StringUtils`. 

Regarding https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/druid-0.10.0/java-util/src/main/java/io/druid/java/util/common/StringUtils.java#L79, added English locale, but a bigger problem is that there are more than 700 direct usages of `String.format()` in the project, made #4335 issue to track that.

BTW @nishantmonu51 I'm not sure that UTF-8 should be used in `DruidKerberosUtil`: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4326/files#diff-642712b19dd6ec8879e4288fef68a75fR84, could you please review that?

hah, thanks for writing this. When the statsd-emitter got released I bumped into this as well and modified the code to replace dots in metric names with underscores as you suggest. Without it, host  names would turn into whole metric paths.
However, I thought that maybe I just wasn't getting how statsd works because the emitter has a way to customize the statsd metric separator. Don't know what it is good for. I tried it out but with no success.

I would like it if people agreed to add this to the upstream statsd emitter. Then I could finally retire our custom implementation and use the upstream code.
I've prepared a patch already, will submit it tomorrow for review ;)

Hi, I might not be the best person to answer your questions, but perhaps you might find the following helpful:
we use Druid for analytical queries and have much larger datasets that Druid run fine on.
For your usecase, we decided to go with lookups. Since the data you need to join in is in the millions, perhaps you need to use the lookups-cached-single extension.

Since you don't have a large dataset, perhaps using a regular relational database is a better fit, especially if you have a lot of writes. Vertica might suit you well. 
In case you'd like to use Druid, there are some caveats with lookups. They are experimental and if used, you need to be careful in cases your lookups are not in a 1:1 relationship with the keys. For instance, we have a lookup that maps a product Id into one of a few product categories.
This lookup works well for splits (i.e. groupings) and we don't notice a performance hit there. However, if a user filters on that lookup definition and innocently selects a single category, then Druid reverse-looks-up all the product IDs and translated the original query into one that now has millions of filter terms. 
Therefore, we try to stick to 1:1 lookup definitions which just rewrite Ids to nice labels. 
There's also support for joins in the works in which smallish datasources get loaded to each cluster node and can then be joined into the master datasource.

Perhaps some of your data needs to receive updates more frequently than other data. You could segregate the data into separate datasources and issue union queries across the datasources.

Because its easier to merge quickly small PRs instead of having them all blocked on all of them passing code review.

And the commit history for extensions vs core becomes cleaner. So when the history of extensions is viewed, the changes for that extension are well isolated and clear.

I'm more interested in the logical separation of

1. Druid core
1. Extensions
1. When looking at the commit history affecting a file, does it make sense, or does it seem like it was changed in a bunch of random pull requests?
1. Anything that has API changes that can affect extensions.

I think 1, 2, and 3 come into play here.

the newest version supports it, but it isn't in a final release state yet:
https://hc.apache.org/news.html

Thought this was a data issue when i first read the description. but that's not the case. its just that the timestamp is not represented in offset but in UTC.

For (1), I agree with using "caffeine" as the default if caching is enabled on broker/historical but no type has been specified.

For (2), since the configuration is different for "local" vs. "caffeine", I think we should just drop the "local" type completely instead of having a transition period where "local" means the same thing as "caffeine" (since the user would have to update to a different configuration format anyway if we switched the implementations internally).

For (3) I don't have a strong opinion; having default behavior rely on an extension feels a little weird to me, if something will always be loaded I feel like it should be in core, but as others have pointed out it could be useful as a reference. 

------

So in terms of a sequence of steps I'm thinking:
1. Update all docs and examples to use "caffeine" as default instead of "local", strongly indicate in the docs that "local" is totally inferior to Caffeine and will be deprecated->removed.
2. Decide after that whether to keep the cache implementations in core or as extensions
3. Remove "local" implementation completely in a later release

-----

For 0.10.1 release, since it looks like it might take some time to reach consensus on all aspects of this issue, should we just update the docs/examples to use Caffeine as default and recommend that users switch from "local"?

Ah, if this is being generated by Hive then please file a bug with the Hive project. The Druid-Hive code lives over there.
The unit tests were meant to work with date time not being timezone aware. I'm assuming we want to be consistent with 0.9.2 so I've changed the unit tests to work accordingly.

This sounds great to me (assuming it doesn't take forever) -- I can think of many examples in the past where issues would only be caught by integration tests, but not unit tests. Mostly issues with service configuration and startup or with interactions between components that are mutually mocked when they interact in unit tests.

yes. That's the reason. 
We've been seeing this as well in Druid 0.9.0, 0.9.1.1, 0.9.2. and 0.10.0

If anyone is interested in fixing this, try starting by searching for calls to `NullDimensionSelector.instance()` (which Druid uses in some cases when it knows a column is missing) and double checking that they are all appropriate. Probably, sometimes it's being called when it really shouldn't be.

There should be some tests too, probably in GroupByQueryRunnerTest and TopNQueryRunnerTest. That just checks reading values though. To check that filtering works too, try adding some tests to the filter test files like SelectorFilterTest and BoundFilterTest.
thanks @b-slim, just a few minor things
@gianm Is the documentation clearer now?
design

I don't think the API for load spec and data puller should change.

This assumes all pullers will always require a copy and a processing of the data, which is not true. It is possible to have a load spec that wires up data without needing to copy/process the data in the way that the s3 puller does currently.

As such caching is a puller property, not a LoadSpec property.
For just my curiosity, what is the exact meaning of the `Design Review` tag? I thought it relates to API changes.
@jihoonson I thought that somebody may have different opinion on how integration tests should be run, maybe in different CI service, etc.

@jihoonson see http://druid.io/community/, it's meant to apply to

- HTTP requests and responses (e. g. a new HTTP endpoint)
- Interfaces for extensions
- Server configuration (e. g. altering the behavior of a config property)
- Emitted metrics
- Other major changes, judged by the discretion of Druid committers

imo, this change isn't that major, but it is up to discretion :)
